Title: Eyespots interact with body colour to protect caterpillar-like prey from avian predators

- "modelled loosely on Papilio canadensis."

  - "Artificial caterpillars were designed to assess the protective value of eyespots and countershading on caterpillar prey in general; however, for ecological relevance, our prey were modelled loosely on Papilio canadensis."
  - "Specifically, pastry caterpillars were manufactured with a 3:1 mixture of white flour (White RoseÔ, White Rose Flour Mills, Byford, WA, U.S.A.) and lard (TenderflakeÔ, Maple Leaf Foods, Toronto, ON, Canada)."

Title: Field experiments on the effectiveness of 'eyespots' as predator deterrents
Authors: Martin Stevens, Elinor Hopkins, William Hinde, Amabel Adcock, Yvonne Connolly, Tom Troscianko, Innes C Cuthill, K T Troscianko
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "For all experiments, artificial moth-like stimuli (not designed to mimic any real species) were made from triangular pieces of waterproof card (HP LaserJet Tough Paper; Hewlett Packard, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.A.), 50 mm wide at the base and 25 mm high, printed with specific patterns on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 4050N printer."
  - "The protocol of each experiment was similar to that of Cuthill et al. (2005). Replicates of each treatment were pinned to trees at a height of between 1 and 2 m with a dead mealworm, Tenebrio molitor, on top (frozen overnight at À80 C and then thawed) to provide an edible component, in Leigh Woods National Nature Reserve, North Somerset, U.K. (2 38.6 0 W, 51 27.8 0 N)."
  - "Eyespots were created in the Java-based imaging program ImageJ (Rasband 1997e2006;Abra `moff et al. 2004), and Photoshop Elements 1.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA, U.S.A.). On each noncontrol target was a pair of eyespots, approximately 7 mm in diameter and 12 mm from the target midline."
Reasoning for "Prey species":
The paper does not mention any specific prey species that was used in the experiments. Instead, the authors used artificial "moth-like stimuli" that were not designed to mimic any real species. This is evident from the following quotes:

"For all experiments, artificial moth-like stimuli (not designed to mimic any real species) were made from triangular pieces of waterproof card (HP LaserJet Tough Paper; Hewlett Packard, Palo Alto, CA, U.S.A.), 50 mm wide at the base and 25 mm high, printed with specific patterns on a Hewlett Packard LaserJet 4050N printer."

"Eyespots were created in the Java-based imaging program ImageJ (Rasband 1997e2006;Abra `moff et al. 2004), and Photoshop Elements 1.0 (Adobe Systems Inc., San Jose, CA, U.S.A.). On each noncontrol target was a pair of eyespots, approximately 7 mm in diameter and 12 mm from the target midline."

"The protocol of each experiment was similar to that of Cuthill et al. (2005). Replicates of each treatment were pinned to trees at a height of between 1 and 2 m with a dead mealworm, Tenebrio molitor, on top (frozen overnight at À80 C and then thawed) to provide an edible component, in Leigh Woods National Nature Reserve, North Somerset, U.K. (2 38.6 0 W, 51 27.8 0 N)."

Title: Significance of butterfly eyespots as an anti-predator device in ground-based and aerial attacks
Authors: Anne Lyytinen, Paul M Brakefield, Johanna Mappes
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "Bicyclus anynana (Satyrinae) shows variation in number, size, shape, colour composition, and position of eyespots (Brakefield and French 1999)."
  - "To test the deflection hypothesis, we compared the survival of the spotless dry season form and spotted wet season form of Bicyclus anynana and examined the target of initial strike."
Reasoning for "Prey species":
The paper clearly states that the prey species used in the experiments was Bicyclus anynana, a satyrine butterfly:
"Bicyclus anynana (Satyrinae) shows variation in number, size, shape, colour composition, and position of eyespots (Brakefield and French 1999)."
"To test the deflection hypothesis, we compared the survival of the spotless dry season form and spotted wet season form of Bicyclus anynana and examined the target of initial strike."
"Furthermore, we used a double mutant line, Bigeye-comet, in which all the eyespots are larger in size than in the wet season form."
The paper does not mention any other prey species being used in the experiments, so the prey species is solely Bicyclus anynana.

Title: The Feeding Behaviour of Starlings (Sturnus vulgaris) in the Presence of 'Eyes'
Authors: I R Inglis, L W Huson, M B Marshall, P A Arid,  Neville
Supporting quotes for "Prey species":
- "BLEST (1957) demonstrated in experiments involving the predation of Aglais urticae by yellow buntings (Emberiza citrinefla) and reed buntings (Emberiza schoenicufus), how essential the patterns are in such defence."
  - "The wings of many insects bear circular patterns, "eyespots" which resemble the vertebrate eye. Eyespot patterns are associated with displays which exhibit them and appear t o be an anti-predator device frequently eliciting flight in the passerine predators of these insects."
Reasoning for "Prey species": The paper does not mention any specific prey species that the eye-like patterns are meant to resemble. The paper focuses on the effects of different eye-like patterns on the feeding behavior of starlings (Sturnus vulgaris), which are the subject species, not the prey species. There is no mention of any butterfly, moth, caterpillar or other prey species that the eye-like patterns are meant to mimic. The paper cites previous work by Blest that found eye-like patterns on butterflies can elicit escape responses in their passerine predators, but the current study does not use any actual prey species.
